column8: MCA is making full use of its governmental position and resources to link small and medium enterprises (SMEs) with China for the benefit of Malaysia’s economy, Datuk Seri Dr Wee Ka Siong (pic) said.The MCA deputy president said MCA was the second party in the country after Umno to have good relations with the Chinese government.He said MCA was a key partner to the nation in building a relationship with China, adding that it was in a good position to help local SMEs break into the Chinese market.“This helps in opening up avenues of discussion with the many levels of the Chinese government, from which much mutually beneficial development can take place,” he said after attending a calligraphy competition prize-giving ceremony yesterday.He hit out at Johor DAP chairman Liew Chin Tong for labelling MCA an “agent of China” without looking at its efforts to create investment opportunities for Malaysians.“He should wake up and see our efforts to help these SMEs regardless of race, to improve the Malaysian economy, from the smallest enterprise to those with an international foothold. And we don’t collect a single sen from them.“Instead of questioning the Barisan Nasional government’s efforts and chiding us on everything we do, DAP must instead show how it plans to bring long-term investments to benefit Malaysia,” he said.On another matter, Dr Wee said that schools which had received government allocations should utilise the funds to develop and upgrade their facilities instead of letting the money sit idle in the bank.It was important to utilise the funds for the benefit of the students so that the schools will have the chance of receiving more allocations in future, he said.“There is no point in keeping the money and it defeats the purpose of asking for an allocation,” he told reporters after distributing cheques to representatives from 89 Chinese schools in Johor.He said the schools received the RM2mil Johor government-allocated funds as promised by Mentri Besar Datuk Seri Mohamed Khaled Nordin following a meeting with MCA in October last year.http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2017...-boost-economy/
